name: Capernaum
shortDescription: Fishing village on the Sea of Galilee that served as Jesus' base of ministry, site of Matthew's calling from the tax booth
fullDescription: Capernaum (Kfar Nahum, 'Village of Nahum') was a prosperous fishing village on the northwestern shore of the Sea of Galilee that became the center of Jesus' Galilean ministry. Located on the Via Maris, the ancient trade route connecting Egypt to Damascus, Capernaum hosted a Roman customs station where tax collectors like Matthew collected duties on goods passing through. It was here that Jesus called Matthew from his tax booth with the simple command 'Follow me' - an invitation that transformed a despised collaborator into a beloved apostle and evangelist. Capernaum witnessed more miracles than any other location in the Gospels: healing of the centurion's servant, Peter's mother-in-law, the paralytic lowered through the roof, the synagogue demoniac, and Jairus's daughter. Jesus taught regularly in its synagogue, whose 4th-century ruins (built on earlier foundations) remain visible today. Despite these mighty works, Capernaum ultimately rejected Jesus, earning his prophetic condemnation: 'And thou, Capernaum, which art exalted unto heaven, shalt be brought down to hell' (Matthew 11:23). The village was abandoned by the 7th century CE and rediscovered by archaeologists in the 19th century. Today, a Franciscan church hovers over what tradition identifies as Peter's house, and pilgrims walk the same stones where Matthew heard the call that changed his life.

geography.location: Northwestern shore of Sea of Galilee, Israel
geography.physicalDescription: Ruins of ancient fishing village on basalt plain near lake shore, with excavated synagogue, houses, and churches

etymology.origin: Hebrew 'Kfar Nahum' - Village of Nahum (the prophet) or Village of Consolation
etymology.development: Hebrew Kfar Nahum -> Greek Kapharnaum -> Latin Capernaum

geographical.culturalArea: Second Temple Jewish Galilee / Roman Palestine

originPoint.name: Capernaum Excavations
originPoint.description: Archaeological site on northwest shore of Sea of Galilee (Lake Kinneret), 3 km from Jordan River inlet

historicalDate.display: c. 2nd century BCE - 7th century CE (active occupation)

timelinePosition.period: Second Temple Period through Byzantine Era
timelinePosition.context: Center of Jesus' ministry for approximately 3 years

keyMoments.significance: After leaving Nazareth, made Capernaum his 'own city' (Matt 9:1)
Tax collector called from booth to become apostle
Jesus pronounces woe for unbelief despite miracles
Byzantine octagonal church marks traditional site
White limestone synagogue built on earlier foundations

events.name: Jesus Makes Capernaum His Home
events.description: After leaving Nazareth, Jesus settled in Capernaum fulfilling Isaiah's prophecy of light dawning in Galilee (Matthew 4:13-16)
events.significance: Established Capernaum as center of Galilean ministry

events.name: Calling of Matthew
events.description: Jesus saw Matthew sitting at the tax booth and called him with the words 'Follow me.' Matthew immediately left everything and followed (Matthew 9:9)
events.significance: Tax collector transformed into apostle and evangelist

events.name: The Feast with Sinners
events.description: Matthew hosted a banquet at his house where Jesus ate with tax collectors and sinners (Matthew 9:10-13)
events.significance: Jesus declared 'I desire mercy, not sacrifice'

events.name: Healing of Centurion's Servant
events.description: Roman centurion's faith amazed Jesus - servant healed at a distance (Matthew 8:5-13)
events.significance: Gentile's faith exceeds Israel's - preview of Great Commission

events.name: Healing of Peter's Mother-in-Law
events.description: Jesus healed Peter's mother-in-law from fever in her Capernaum home (Matthew 8:14-15)
events.significance: Early miracle establishing Jesus' healing ministry

events.name: Healing of the Paralytic
events.description: Four men lowered paralyzed friend through roof; Jesus forgave sins and healed him (Mark 2:1-12)
events.significance: Jesus demonstrates authority to forgive sins

events.name: Synagogue Teaching and Exorcism
events.description: Jesus taught with authority in Capernaum synagogue and cast out demon (Mark 1:21-28)
events.significance: Demons recognize Jesus as 'Holy One of God'

events.name: Raising of Jairus's Daughter
events.description: Jesus raised synagogue ruler's daughter from death (Mark 5:21-43)

events.name: Bread of Life Discourse
events.description: After feeding 5000, Jesus taught in Capernaum synagogue about being the bread of life (John 6:24-59)
events.significance: Many disciples left after this teaching; core disciples remained

events.name: Woe Against Capernaum
events.description: Jesus pronounced judgment: 'Thou, Capernaum, which art exalted unto heaven, shalt be brought down to hell' (Matthew 11:23)
events.significance: Privilege brings greater accountability; prophecy fulfilled in city's destruction

mythologyContexts.usage: Center of Jesus' Galilean ministry; site of Matthew's calling; location of many miracles and teachings; Jesus' 'own city'

textReferences.context: Jesus' Galilean headquarters and Matthew's calling
Bread of Life discourse in synagogue

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Capernaum represents both the privilege of divine presence and the danger of familiarity breeding contempt. Despite witnessing more miracles than any other city, Capernaum failed to repent, earning Jesus' severe condemnation. The city symbolizes the transformation possible through encounter with Christ (Matthew's calling) and the judgment awaiting those who reject such grace.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Major Christian pilgrimage site since Byzantine era. Excavations reveal 1st-century houses, 4th-century synagogue, and octagonal church over Peter's house. Modern Franciscan church (built 1990) hovers over traditional site of Peter's home. Site demonstrates continuity between Gospel narratives and archaeological evidence.

mythologyContexts.usage: Galilean fishing village with synagogue; located on Via Maris trade route
mythologyContexts.symbolism: Represents Galilean Jewish life in Second Temple period - fishing economy, Roman occupation, synagogue worship, trade route commerce
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Archaeological evidence of Galilean Jewish village life; one of best-preserved 1st-century synagogues in Israel

inhabitants.name: Jesus
inhabitants.description: Made Capernaum his base during Galilean ministry

inhabitants.name: Peter
inhabitants.description: Fisherman whose house became center of activity

inhabitants.name: Matthew/Levi
inhabitants.description: Tax collector called from booth in Capernaum

inhabitants.name: Andrew
inhabitants.description: Fisherman, brother of Peter, from Capernaum area

texts.name: Gospel of Matthew
texts.relationship: Documents Matthew's calling and Capernaum ministry

saw a man named Matthew sitting at the receipt of custom
when Jesus was entered into Capernaum there came unto him a centurion

metadata.agentPerspective: Site of Matthew's calling and transformation
